sentences.sentence: The next day the little prince came back.
“It would have been better to come back at the same hour,” said the fox. “If, for example, you come at four o’clock in the afternoon, then at three o’clock I shall begin to be happy.
I shall feel happier and happier as the hour advances. At four o’clock, I shall already be worrying and jumping about. I shall show you how happy I am!
But if you come at just any time, I shall never know at what hour my heart is to be ready to greet you . . . One must observe the proper rites( 仪式 ) . . .”
“What is a rite( 仪式 )?” asked the little prince.
“Those also are actions too often neglected( 被忽略的 ),” said the fox. “They are what make one day different from other days, one hour from other hours.
There is a rite( 仪式 ), for example, among my hunters. Every Thursday they dance with the village girls.
So Thursday is a wonderful day for me! I can take a walk as far as the vineyards( 葡萄园 ).
But if the hunters danced at just any time, every day would be like every other day, and I should never have any vacation at all.”
So the little prince tamed( 驯化 ) the fox. And when the hour of his departure( 离去 ) drew near( 临近 )—
“Ah,” said the fox, “I shall cry.”
“It is your own fault,” said the little prince. “I never wished you any sort of harm; but you wanted me to tame( 驯化 ) you . . .”
“Yes, that is so,” said the fox.
“But now you are going to cry!” said the little prince.
“Yes, that is so,” said the fox.
“Then it has done you no good at all!”
“It has done me good,” said the fox, “because of the color of the wheat fields.” And then he added:
“Go and look again at the roses. You will understand now that yours is unique( 独一无二的 ) in all the world. Then come back to say goodbye to me, and I will make you a present of a secret.”
The little prince went away, to look at the roses.
“You are not at all like my rose,” he said. “As yet you are nothing. No one has tamed( 驯化 ) you, and you have tamed( 驯化 ) no one.
You are like my fox when I first knew him. He was only a fox like a hundred thousand other foxes. But I have made him my friend, and now he is unique( 独一无二的 ) in all the world.”
And the roses were very much embarrassed( 窘迫的 ).
“You are beautiful, but you are empty,” he went on.
“One could not die for you. To be sure, an ordinary passerby( 路人 ) would think that my rose looked just like you—the rose that belongs to( 属于 ) me.
But in herself alone she is more important than all the hundreds of you other roses: because it is she that I have watered;
because it is she that I have put under the glass globe; because it is she that I have sheltered( 为...提供庇护所 ) behind the screen;
because it is for her that I have killed the caterpillars( 毛虫 ) (except the two or three that we saved to become butterflies);
because it is she that I have listened to, when she grumbled( 发牢骚 ), or boasted( 自夸 ), or even sometimes when she said nothing. Because she is my rose.”
And he went back to meet the fox.
“Goodbye,” he said.
“Goodbye,” said the fox. “And now here is my secret, a very simple secret: It is only with the heart that one can see rightly; what is essential( 本质的 ) is invisible( 看不见的 ) to the eye.”
“What is essential( 本质的 ) is invisible( 看不见的 ) to the eye,” the little prince repeated, so that he would be sure to remember.
“It is the time you have wasted for your rose that makes your rose so important.”
“It is the time I have wasted for my rose—” said the little prince, so that he would be sure to remember.
“Men have forgotten this truth,” said the fox. “But you must not forget it. You become responsible, forever, for what you have tamed( 驯化 ). You are responsible for your rose . . .”
“I am responsible for my rose,” the little prince repeated, so that he would be sure to remember.
“Good morning,” said the little prince.
“Good morning,” said the railway switchman( 扳道工 ).
“What do you do here?” the little prince asked.
“I sort out( 安顿 ) travelers, in bundles of( 一批批 ) a thousand,” said the switchman( 扳道工 ). “I send off( 送走 )the trains that carry them; now to the right, now to the left.”
And a brilliantly lighted express train( 特快列车 ) shook the switchman( 扳道工 )’s cabin( 小屋 ) as it rushed by with a roar( 轰鸣声 ) like thunder.
“They are in a great hurry,” said the little prince. “What are they looking for?”
“Not even the locomotive( 火车头 ) engineer knows that,” said the switchman( 扳道工 ).
And a second brilliantly lighted express thundered by, in the opposite direction.
“Are they coming back already?” demanded the little prince.
“These are not the same ones,” said the switchman( 扳道工 ). “It is an exchange.”
“Were they not satisfied where they were?” asked the little prince.
“No one is ever satisfied where he is,” said the switchman( 扳道工 ).
And they heard the roaring( 轰鸣的 ) thunder of a third brilliantly lighted express.
“Are they pursuing( 追赶 ) the first travelers?” demanded the little prince.
“They are pursuing( 追赶 ) nothing at all,” said the switchman( 扳道工 ).
“They are asleep in there, or if they are not asleep they are yawning( 打呵欠 ). Only the children are flattening their noses against the windowpanes( 窗玻璃 ).”
“Only the children know what they are looking for,” said the little prince.
“They waste their time over a rag doll and it becomes very important to them; and if anybody takes it away from them, they cry . . .”
“They are lucky,” the switchman( 扳道工 ) said.
“Good morning,” said the little prince.
“Good morning,” said the merchant( 商人 ).
This was a merchant( 商人 ) who sold pills that had been invented to quench thirst( 止渴 ).
You need only swallow one pill a week, and you would feel no need of anything to drink.
“Why are you selling those?” asked the little prince.
“Because they save a tremendous( 大量的 ) amount of time,” said the merchant( 商人 ).
“Computations( 计算 ) have been made by experts. With these pills, you save fifty-three minutes in every week.”
“And what do I do with those fifty-three minutes?”
“Anything you like . . .”
“As for me,” said the little prince to himself, “if I had fifty-three minutes to spend as I liked, I should walk at my leisure( 空闲时 ) toward a spring of fresh water.”

article_info.previous: 小王子穿越沙漠，在花园中看到满园的玫瑰，十分惊讶的同时，他也很难过他的玫瑰花竟然不是宇宙中唯一的一朵。然后他遇见了狐狸，狐狸想让小王子驯化他。
article_info.share_words: “Goodbye,” said the fox. “And now here is my secret, a very simple secret: It is only with the heart that one can see rightly; what is essential is invisible to the eye.”

question.cn: 一周中，狐狸最喜欢哪一天？
question.en: Which day did the fox like best in a week?

analysis: 原文里，狐狸说：There is a rite, for example, among my hunters. Every Thursday they dance with the village girls. So Thursday is a wonderful day for me! I can take a walk as far as the vineyards. 所以答案为C。

question.cn: 根据小王子的说法，人如何才能正确地看待事情呢？
question.en: According to the fox, how can one see things rightly?

analysis: 原文提到：“Goodbye,” said the fox. “And now here is my secret, a very simple secret: It is only with the heart that one can see rightly; what is essential is invisible to the eye.”所以答案为B。

question.cn: 按狐狸的说法，小王子要对谁负责？
question.en: According to the fox, whom was the little prince responsible for??

analysis: 原文提到：“Men have forgotten this truth,” said the fox. “But you must not forget it. You become responsible, forever, for what you have tamed. You are responsible for your rose . . .”所以答案为B.

question.cn: 小王子离开狐狸之后，他遇见了谁？
question.en: Who did the little prince meet after he left the fox?

analysis: 在原文中，小王子离开狐狸之后曾有过一段对话：“Good morning,” said the little prince.“Good morning,” said the railway switchman.所以答案为B。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第11天
